resources.string: Tap on anything above to learn more.

SSID stands for Service Set IDentifier. It is the name of the WiFi network visible to the phone.
Different access points can have the same SSID - they are not necessarily unique. Multiple access points with the same SSID are often seen around large campuses, where an organization like a school or business might use several access points to extend a single WiFi network over a large area.

BSSID stands for Basic Service Set IDentifier. It is a number which is unique to a specific access point. The access point uses it to identify itself to the phone and other computers over the internet. It is equivalent to the access point's MAC address.

The capabilities string gives certain technical information about the network. Here is a summary of some of the more common acronyms:
WEP, WPA, WPA2: Signifies the method the network uses to encrypt your data. WEP is the oldest and least secure method, while WPA2 is the newest and most secure. Any letters immediately following one of these separated by hyphens indicate more specific information about the access point\'s encryption and data transfer protocols.
ESS stands for Extended Service Set, meaning that this access point is one of multiple that all share the same network.

The frequency a WiFi access point can determine its range and speed. Higher frequencies (in the 5000 Mhz range) will allow data transfer but can only operate over a relatively small area. Lower frequencies (in the 2400 Mhz range) serve a wider range at the cost of slower service speed. Access points with frequencies too close together (within 10 Mhz) can interfere and cause data loss and therefore slower speeds.

The channel is a number assigned to a specific frequency. To avoid interfering with other types of wireless signals like BlueTooth or cellular signals, only certain frequencies can be used for WiFi, and each of these is given a channel number by convention.

This box shows basic information about a WiFi wireless access point. "Access point" here signifies the physical router that is transmitting the WiFi signal. A WiFi network is composed of one or more access points.
The icon to the left of the box indicates the strength of the signal received by your phone from this access point.
To the right of the icon is the name of the access point, consisting of the name (SSID) of the WiFi network and, optionally, a number to differentiate access points with the same SSID. Note that this number is not actually determined by anything about the access point itself, but is assigned by this app to the access points in the order they are first seen, and so may differ from phone to phone.
On the right side of the box is the numerical value of the power (strength) of the WiFi signal, given in two different units. Dbm (decibel-milliwatts) is a logarithmic unit, so that increasing the number by ten actually indicates an increase of ten times the power. Pw (picowatts) is a normal linear unit, so doubling the number indicates a doubling of power.
